sub_topic: Calculation of entropy change for a chemical reaction
message_1: What is the standard entropy change of the combustion reaction of methane gas under standard conditions?
message_2:
To calculate the standard entropy change (ΔS°) of the combustion reaction of methane gas under standard conditions, we need to know the standard molar entropies (S°) of the reactants and products involved in the reaction. The combustion reaction of methane can be represented as:

CH₄(g) + 2O₂(g) → CO₂(g) + 2H₂O(g)

The standard molar entropies (S°) at 298 K for the substances involved are:

S°(CH₄) = 186.3 J/mol·K
S°(O₂) = 205.2 J/mol·K
S°(CO₂) = 213.8 J/mol·K
S°(H₂O) = 188.8 J/mol·K

Now, we can calculate the standard entropy change (ΔS°) using the formula:

ΔS° = ΣS°(products) - ΣS°(reactants)

ΔS° = [1 × S°(CO₂) + 2 × S°(H₂O)] - [1 × S°(CH₄) + 2 × S°(O₂)]

ΔS° = [1 × 213.8 + 2 × 188.8] - [1 × 186.3 + 2 × 205.2]

ΔS° = (213.8 + 377.6) - (186.3 + 410.4)

ΔS° = 591.4 - 596.7

ΔS° = -5.3 J/mol·K

The standard entropy change of the combustion reaction of methane gas under standard conditions is -5.3 J/mol·K.
